comp

Class MazeMath

  • java.lang.Object
    • comp.MazeMath

  • public class MazeMath
extends java.lang.Object
    This class provides useful methods to operate on to arrays/lists and convert between the directional systems of Floorplan, Distance, CardinalDirection, Robot.Direction and Robot.Turn, which can be used by other classes without hassle. At the moment intended for use in Robot class and anything that may operate it, including BasicRobotTest and RobotDriver.
    Author:
    Elijah Mas

    • Field Detail

      • WestSouthEastNorth

        public static final ExtendedList<CardinalDirection> WestSouthEastNorth

        ArrayList that enumerates cardinal directions in order of rotating rightwards, starting at West.

        Instantiated as a list rather than an array to utilize the List.indexOf method.

      • ForwardRightBackwardLeft

        public static final ExtendedList<Robot.Direction> ForwardRightBackwardLeft

        The four values of Robot.Direction starting at forward and rotating rightward.

        Maintained as a separate array from Direction.values() so as to not rely on the order of elements in Direction.

        public static CardinalDirection convertDirs(Robot.Direction d,
                                            CardinalDirection currentDirection)
        Translate relative direction to absolute direction given knowledge of how current direction relates to forward direction. Meant for usage pertinent to a Robot instance.
        Parameters:
        d - a value of Robot.Direction
        currentDirection - CardinalDirection corresponding to current forward direction (meant for a robot)
        Returns:
        CardinalDirection corresponding to input direction

      • convertDirs

        public static Robot.Direction convertDirs(CardinalDirection input,
                                          CardinalDirection currentDirection)
        Convert an absolute CardinalDirection to a relative {@link Direction). Requires knowledge of the absolute direction corresponding to the forward direction.
        Parameters:
        input - the CardinalDirection to convert
        currentDirection - the CardinalDirection that gives the same direction as the forward direction
        Returns:
        the analogous Robot.Direction

      • directionToTurn

        public static Robot.Turn directionToTurn(Robot.Direction d)
        Convert a Robot.Direction value to a Robot.Turn value; since both values indicate some form of relative direction, there is a one-to-one correspondence.
        Parameters:
        d - a Robot.Direction value
        Returns:
        the turn that will put us facing the specified direction

      • getNewDirectionReferenceOverTurn

        public static Robot.Direction getNewDirectionReferenceOverTurn(Robot.Direction d,
                                                               Robot.Turn turn)

        Relative to the current forward direction, get the new relative directional reference to some direction d resulting from a turn.

        Example: consider a robot's LEFT direction. The robot rotates RIGHT. The direction formerly referenced as LEFT is now referenced as BACKWARDS.

        Another way of phrasing this: in the above example, say the robot before the turn is in state 1 and after the turn in state 2. Then the robot's notion of left in state 1 and the robot's notion of backwards in state 2 both point to the same absolute direction.

        Parameters:
        d - a Robot.Direction value
        turn - a Robot.Turn value
        Returns:
        the direction resulting from the specified turn

      • getTurnIndex

        public static int getTurnIndex(Robot.Turn t)
        The index of a turn is the distance one would have to move from the current location in a right-moving ordered array to reach the location specified by the turn
        Parameters:
        t - a Robot.Turn value
        Returns:
        index of the turn
